The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some controversy. In particular, there is no consensus on the precise nature of the mathematical objects that quantum theory deals with. This paper provides a categorical characterization of the category of observables in terms of a set of purely categorical axioms. The axioms are shown to be sufficient to characterize the category of observables, and they are shown to be necessary if one assumes the existence of a basis for states. The characterization is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. The characterization is shown to be consistent with the standard interpretation of quantum mechanics. The characterization is shown to be consistent with the operational interpretation of quantum mechanics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, but a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic assemblies for two species of myxozoans, which represent the most distant species pairs in the group. We show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. We also show that myxozoans are one of the most reduced animal groups, with a small genome and gene content. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. COVID-19 is a serious global health problem that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The current pandemic has led to the development of a number of vaccines and therapeutic strategies. However, the development of new antiviral drugs is still needed. In this study, we identified a viral protein that is able to block the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, which are key factors in the IFN-mediated antiviral response. Our results provide a better understanding of the mechanism of action of SARS-CoV-2 and suggest a potential target for the development of new antiviral drugs.

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world will need to produce more food to feed a projected 10 billion people by the middle of the 21st century. This will be challenging as the Earth’s climate continues to warm. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded. Here, we show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially as the global mean temperature increases, and that this variability will increase even more if the temperature increases are larger. This variability will increase the risk of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in the world’s major maize-exporting countries, and will likely increase the risk of international price spikes. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize for heat tolerance.

The coexistence of species with different feeding preferences is a fundamental ecological principle. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species, even among species matched in body size and digestive physiology. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammalian herbivore assemblages. Our findings highlight the importance of diet composition in determining trophic interactions, and the need to consider the taxonomic resolution of diet data when investigating the coexistence of species.

We provide evidence on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on small businesses. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, many small businesses are financially fragile. Finally, many small businesses anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris in the ocean interior and on the surface.

The solar system is a unique laboratory to study the history of the interstellar medium. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since the 1950s, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a fifth since the 1950s, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of the global fleet has decreased by a third since 2000, and there are signs of stabilization and more effective management in recent years.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this paper, we show that the ability to provide energy to the offspring during pregnancy is a key factor in determining the reproductive output of mammals.

The results of this study suggest that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study also provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in a mouse model of a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and the primary target of many drugs and diseases. The endothelium is a network of cells that communicate with each other and with other cells in the body. This paper describes the structure of the endothelial communication network and its properties that make it effective for the efficient control of vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are needed by many different audiences. We describe the data sources and signals that we have developed to provide open access to COVID-19 activity in the United States, including both traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. These data are available through an API, which is open to the public and provides access to data in a common format. We demonstrate the utility of the data by showing how they can be used to track COVID-19 activity, augment traditional public health reporting, and empower research and decision-making. We hope that this API will be useful to many different audiences, and that it will help to inform the response to the pandemic.

This work provides a structural and mechanistic explanation for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. This communication is essential for the proper functioning of these channels, which are involved in a wide range of physiological processes.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms that are essential for the health of the animal. The role of fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood, but they are likely to be important in the health of the animal. This study shows that fungi in the gut of herbivores produce a variety of natural products, which could be used as a source of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes an individual to become subordinate in a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. This finding is important, as the nucleus accumbens is a key brain region involved in the regulation of social behavior. Our results indicate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious individuals is not due to a lack of motivation to do so but rather to a reduced ability to do so. This is a significant finding, as it points to a potential avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns are often predetermined. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures with arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations, which is based on the inverse design approach and the digital synthesis of multiple hyperelastic materials. The synthesized structures are composed of different materials with distinct behaviors, which are seamlessly integrated through sophisticated deformation mechanisms. The proposed strategy can be extended to design structures with complex and programmable responses. The discovered structures are effective in experiments and can be utilized to design mechanical devices with specific responses for a wide range of applications.

This study provides a mechanism for the heterochronic regulation of fetal hemoglobin in humans. The results suggest that the IGF2BP1 protein may be a key component in the regulation of the hemoglobin switch in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of new therapies, the survival rate of cancer patients has not improved in the last 40 y. This is due to the emergence of drug resistance, which is often mediated by mutations in key signaling pathways. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We show that this resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, drives lipogenesis and resistance to ferroptosis. We also show that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, and that this combination therapy is effective in preclinical models. These findings provide a potential strategy for the treatment of cancer. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, the most common form of heart disease. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the prevention of heart failure. The most widely used drugs for the treatment of hypertension are the L-type calcium channel blockers (LCCBs). These drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. Here, we show that LCCBs activate a store-operated calcium channel in vascular smooth muscle cells, which promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings may help to explain the higher risk of heart failure associated with LCCBs and may lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of hypertension.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring and adaptive management, and was the first plan to use the concept of multiple use. We show that the NWFP has had a significant effect on the composition of forests, but not on the biodiversity it was intended to protect.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. We present a new deep learning architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different scales, and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data, and is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on several segmentation problems. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The climate of the tropics is a critical component of the global energy budget, and the transport of moisture is a key process in the global water cycle. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The shift in hydroclimate at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition is consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The record provides a unique window into the past climate of the tropics, and the influence of orbital forcing on the evolution of the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock. The record also demonstrates the ability of the lake to respond rapidly to changes in climate. View Full-Text

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-shift the circadian clock, and reduce sleep quality. These effects are likely to have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) chronostratigraphic boundary is the most prominent event in the last 10,000 y in terms of its impact on human history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB is consistent with terrestrial sources, and that the Os in the magnetic grains and microspherules is likely derived from a terrestrial source. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We present a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of beetles, including the first estimates of beetle diversification rates. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our algorithm can be used to optimize the sequences of the complementarity-determining regions (CDRs) of antibodies, which are the most variable regions of the antibody. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. The inner core is a unique natural material that is not found on the surface of the Earth. The formation of the inner core is one of the most important events in the history of the Earth. However, the mechanism of the inner core formation is still a mystery. In this paper, we provide a new insight into the formation of the inner core by showing that the bcc phase of iron is more likely to nucleate than the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. View Full-Text

This study provides evidence that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). The reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings have implications for the understanding of the neurobiology of addiction and the development of effective treatments.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s processing of language is a central focus of neuroscience. Here, we show that the latest advances in deep learning can predict the brain’s responses to language better than any previous model. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the latest advances in deep learning may be a powerful tool for understanding the brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that this black box can be made to work, but only at a high cost in terms of the number of training samples and the accuracy of the solution. Our results are based on the theory of numerical linear algebra, which is a well-established field. We believe that this theory will be useful in the development of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a case study in the failure of science communication. The scientific community has been unable to come to terms with the fact that the public does not understand exponential growth. This paper shows that the public’s lack of understanding is not a new phenomenon, but rather a well-established problem that has been studied for decades.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and has been the subject of much study. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nervous system, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon. Here we present the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, and compare it with that of M. leprae. We find that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause disease in the nervous system, and that the two species are remarkably similar in genome content and organization. This suggests that they have been able to maintain their pathogenicity for thousands of years. (Less)

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a central topic of current research. However, the study of interacting systems is hampered by the lack of a complete description of the dynamics. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit can be fully understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, which is not feasible for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a vaccine that is easy to manufacture, can be administered as a single dose, and is highly protective.

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats spread the disease. However, the role of human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas or lice, has been overlooked. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353).

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of brain power. However, this approach is biased because it does not take into account the fact that brains are not only bigger but also more powerful when they are more complex. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is not only different from the evolution of brain size but also has a different pattern of evolution.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. Severing is a key process in many biological contexts, including cell migration, cell division, and the formation of the actin cortex. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin severes filaments remains unclear. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin binds to filaments and that this binding induces a mechanical torque on the filaments. This torque enhances severing by orders of magnitude, and we propose that it is critical for ADF/cofilin to sever highly connected filaments in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF/cofilin sever actin filaments, and they have implications for our understanding of the role of ADF/cofilin in severing in cells.

Fructose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, a sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative effects of these two sugars on brain and behavior are not well understood. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes greater hunger and desire for food and a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. Further research is needed to determine whether these findings can be generalized to the general population and to determine whether the effects of fructose are due to its unique chemical properties or to other factors, such as the beverages in which it is found. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, which allowed us to study the human history of the island in a way that was not possible before. We find that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed, but the settlement was not homogeneous across the island. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the human history of Madagascar. We show that the content of a social network can influence the emotions of its users. This work suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

This study is focused on the effects of a modification that is present in the coding regions of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and is found in the majority of mRNAs in the human transcriptome. The modification is pseudouridine (Ψ), and it is found in the 5′ mRNA sequence. We show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the bacterial translation system and human cells. This study suggests that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can lead to a modest change in the rate of protein synthesis. This finding may be important for the regulation of protein synthesis in cells. (Read more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.
The evolution of body size is a central question in biology. Here, we show that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is consistent with the energetic demands of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the major cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, at least in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

This study demonstrates that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a mechanochemical sensor for the detection of surfaces. This is the first example of a bacterial mechanosensory system.

This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global risk of pesticide contamination of surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.
This study is the first to document the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer. The findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The paper is about the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the number of people with the disease is expected to increase dramatically in the coming decades. The cause of AD is not known, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we show that the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) in the brain is the primary cause of an inflammatory response in neurons, which in turn leads to the formation of Aβ plaques and neurofibrillary tangles.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus) is one of the most important events in the history of agriculture. However, the earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens is still missing. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant already in the fourth century B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for the use of chickens in the economy.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how many distinct intermediates are involved. This work shows that a large protein, MBP, folds through at least two distinct intermediates, one of which is a folding intermediate that is not adjacent to the native state. This work adds to the growing list of proteins that fold through distinct intermediates.
This is a study of the interplay between the structure of RNA and the mechanism of its degradation.

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. Although the immune system is activated in response to the presence of pathogens, it can also become dysfunctional, leading to the development of severe sepsis. In this study, we demonstrate that citrulline, an amino acid that is not essential for survival, can be used as a therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression in a mouse model of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. View Full-Text

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves in such a way that small perturbations grow to large ones, and vice versa, on a time scale that is much slower than the intrinsic time scale of the system. SOC is observed in a variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, fire spreading, neural networks, and fracture dynamics. In this paper, we report on the discovery of a continuous model of SOC.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum applications. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.
This work is a contribution to the field of peptide-based therapeutics. It is also a contribution to the field of plant disease management.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely to be a site of molecular continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these contributions are enriched for proteins involved in energy metabolism. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα). Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches the A1 domain in VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. The mechanism is similar to that of other proteins, and the results explain the effects of mutations in VWD. The results also suggest that the A1 domain of VWF is a promising target for the treatment of VWD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, due to the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses from human metagenomic samples, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. The database is used to show that viruses are associated with a wide variety of diseases, and to show that the virome is more complex than the bacteriome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL is able to measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously, which is not possible with current remote-sensing techniques. The HSRL was used to conduct a case study over Beijing, China. The results show that the HSRL is able to provide new insights into ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. It is expected to provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI. This technique is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is inferred from the isotopic compositions of marine cherts, which, however, have been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes, which provide an independent method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic evidence. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the primary regulators of ion flow. They are also the targets of drugs and toxins. The K+ channel, the BK channel, is the most abundant K+ channel in the body. It is a major target of hypertension drugs. The BK channel is also a major target of the toxin, ricin. We found that the BK channel is a unique K+ channel in that it shows slow C-type inactivation and that its C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 600,000 deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface and alters the biophysical properties of the cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface, altering the physical properties of the cell, and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new antimalarial strategies.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum applications. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we show that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus disease, and suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza infection. Our findings may also have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus disease in the context of climate change.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic phrases as it processes the sequence of words in a sentence. Whether and how this structure is represented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power in multiple areas of the brain increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words merge into phrases. This pattern of activity suggests that the brain uses a merge operation to build phrases from words, and that the operation applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial evidence for a neural implementation of a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. They also suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be important for efficient language processing.

We show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also in their regulation. This is a very important finding, as it shows that the regulation of redundant genes can be used to control the response to a signal. This is a very important feature in biology, as it allows for the control of the response to a signal.
This is a study of the brain circuit that may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most essential nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is the major factor limiting crop yields. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, and to direct them to a desired host plant, would therefore be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, and to direct them to a desired host plant, by engineering the communication between plants and bacteria.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing anthropogenic particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death, and the need for a safe and effective vaccine remains. Here we report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein, which mediates viral entry to cells, that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern, and presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that this variant may be a suitable subunit vaccine candidate for global access.

The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in the history of infectious disease. The study of ancient plague genomes provides a unique window into the early evolution of this devastating disease. Here, we present 17 plague genomes from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia, spanning the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. View Full-Text

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (i.e., hegemonic masculinity) and support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The agricultural management of grasslands and the integration of livestock has the potential to sequester carbon in the soil. However, the results of these practices are highly variable and depend on the soil type, climate, and management system. We show that the management of grasslands and the integration of livestock can increase soil carbon storage on Mollisols, but the results of these practices are highly variable. These results highlight the importance of the soil type, climate, and management system and the need for more research on the effects of these practices on soil carbon storage in different climates and soil types.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover to humans. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that many animals seek out in order to obtain pollen and/or seeds. In this paper, we show that the color of nectar is a trait that has been independently evolved in two different groups of plants, and that the color red is a particularly attractive color to vertebrate pollinators.

The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations of people and animals, and the impact of these on the genetic structure of the continent. However, the impact of these processes on the genetic structure of the population during the period between the migrations is not well understood. Here we present a study of the genetic structure of a group of individuals from the Early Medieval period in Europe, and show that the genetic structure of the population during this period was more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a major cause of severe pneumonia in humans. The virus is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand the potential of HKU4 and HKU5 to cause human infections, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The study also highlights the potential of mNGS to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. The study also demonstrates the feasibility of using mNGS to conduct pathogen surveillance in resource-limited settings. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it is possible to evolve ribozymes that can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template, but it is not known whether such ribozymes can replicate RNA. Here, we show that an improved version of the RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a new disease, and the pathogenesis is still unclear. The immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 have been analyzed, and the pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality. The results provide a reference for the clinical treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause severe damage to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of metal-binding natural products is described here for the first time.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph that is not stable at the present day surface of the planet. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous material is a mixture of precipitated silica, leachates, and/or fracture/vein fillings. The diagenesis of the amorphous material is consistent with multiple aqueous fluid events, and the presence of an acidic fluid is supported by the presence of sulfate and phosphate salts. The diagenesis of the amorphous material is consistent with the presence of acidic fluids, and the presence of an acidic fluid is supported by the presence of sulfate and phosphate salts.

Frost events are a major source of crop and animal losses, and their frequency is expected to increase in a warmer world. However, the geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the geographic distribution of tree species’ frost resistance strategies. Our results suggest that the geographic distribution of frost events is likely to change in the future, and that the geographic distribution of frost resistance strategies will change in the past.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of this disease is not clear. Here we show that the development of colitis in a model of Th17 cell transfer required the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells and was dependent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in several genes, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced astrocytes, which can be used to study the disease in vitro. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This study will help to accelerate the development of therapies for ALS. The study of the evolution of the avian tail is important for understanding the origin of flight. However, the known diversity of early pygostylians is limited, obscuring our understanding of the transition from long-tailed basal birds to the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the origin of the modern avian tail.
We show that the tropical tropopause layer plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change color. This ability is important for the animal’s survival, as it allows them to adapt to their environment. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of vertebrates.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a method that allows the identification of the animal origin of parchment, which is of great importance for the study of the history of codices and the development of parchment production.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a critical control on the interpretation of the causes and mechanisms of the event. Here we present a precise age model for the extinction, which reveals that the onset of the extinction was not instantaneous and that the carbon cycle was highly variable prior to the recovery of the ecosystem. These results will improve our understanding of the extinction and its aftermath, and will be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)
This study provides a new understanding of the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD.

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in the closed and open states. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has led to a more open conformation, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion with the cell membrane.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, a decline of 1.13 y, and at age 65 y, 83.36 y, a decline of 0.87 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical behavior of atoms and molecules is a key factor in the origin of life and the evolution of the Earth. The chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, are key factors in the understanding of chemical phenomena, including the origin of life. Here, we show that these two properties decrease with pressure, and we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure, which is a key factor in the origin of life and the evolution of the Earth.

We show that human ignitions and suppression have been a major driver of changes in fire activity over the past century. However, the trajectory of future fire activity is uncertain, and we find that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to understand the effects of climate change on fire regimes, as well as the effects of human ignitions and suppression.

This is a study of the symbiosis between a host and a microbe. The host is a squid, and the microbe is a bacterium. The bacterium lives inside the squid, and the squid provides nutrients to the bacterium. The bacterium provides a light show for the squid.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning, which have led to the development of a new type of vector representation of words. We show that this representation can be used to model the structure of a corpus, and that it can be used to identify topics that are not captured by existing structured variables. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains, and it can be applied to structured and unstructured data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The introduction of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes bubonic plague, is generally understood as the cause of the pandemic. However, the location of the putative reservoirs of the rodent reservoir hosts of the bacterium is still a matter of debate. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were highly correlated in the centuries preceding the outbreaks, and that this correlation was not explained by the climate conditions in Europe. Our results suggest that the climate conditions in Asia were the main driver of the introduction of the bacterium into Europe.

Asteroids are a keystone species in the marine ecosystem, and their loss has significant consequences for the ecosystem. We present evidence that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality in a marine invertebrate.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We further show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP has strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that this antibody can be used to treat primary human AML cells in vitro. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, which allowed us to study the human history of Madagascar in a way that was not possible before. We find that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed, but the settlement was not homogeneous across the island. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We also show that the RNA also encodes a protein that interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. This demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete with each other. This is an example of a mechanism that has evolved to regulate the activity of an sRNA. This mechanism is likely to be common in bacteria, and may be important in the regulation of carbon metabolism in bacteria.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our algorithm can be used to optimize the sequences of the CDR regions of antibodies, which are the most important regions for binding to the target. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our algorithm can also be used to optimize other protein molecules. This work highlights the power of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to convert the original data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the use of crop expert assessments can improve the accuracy of agricultural monitoring systems. This work is a step towards the use of the full potential of the network of “people as sensors” that are crop experts.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a sustained increase in neural activity. However, there is also evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation plays a role in memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can be used to store information in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the response of soil respiration to experimental warming remains unclear. We present the results of a comprehensive analysis of the temperature response of soil respiration to experimental warming in nine biomes, which represents the largest global dataset to date. Our results provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most important events in the evolution of the plastid genome, which is the site of photosynthesis in plants. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of improving the representation of the complex dynamics of the South African climate in climate models. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of droughts in SSA.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy that is used by all life. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is accomplished by the capture of light by pigments, the conversion of light energy to chemical energy, and the storage of this energy in the form of ATP and NADPH. The biosynthesis of the pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by the interaction of multiple genetic variants and environmental factors. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Our results show that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The study of the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. This study provides a detailed description of the process of spreading in a model system, which can be used to further our understanding of the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases.

Bats are the most diverse group of mammals and are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the bat salivary gland and provides immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting the immunosuppressant protein.
