Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are involved in a variety of cellular processes. However, the proteins that are responsible for the formation of inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not part of these processes. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. We suggest that the presence of these proteins in inclusions is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, which leads to the formation of inclusions. This study suggests that the inclusion bodies in ALS are a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The study of Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, is of great importance for the understanding of the evolution of angiosperms. Montsechia is the oldest known angiosperm, and its study has led to a better understanding of the evolution of the angiosperm family Ceratophyllaceae.

The study of ancient viruses is important for understanding the evolution of viruses, and in particular, the origin of viruses. Here, we present the genomes of five ancient viruses from human remains that lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. View Full-Text

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of global change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. The increase seen across birth cohorts cannot be explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity for the less educated, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The application of NMR to the study of enzymes has been transformative, providing a means to probe the structure and dynamics of enzymes in solution. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the power of NMR to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions, and the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates. This work also demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in the study of a reaction that is not amenable to solution NMR. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease. There is no specific treatment, and no licensed antiviral. Remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral, has shown promising activity in vitro and in vivo, and is currently being tested in a clinical trial. Here, we show that remdesivir is highly effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses, and may be considered for a wider range of viral infections in the future.

This is a study of the role of a single molecule in the life of a symbiotic organism. The glycan chitin is produced by the host squid, and is released in a specific time and place, in a manner that is dependent on the size of the symbiont population. This glycan is then catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the products of its catabolism to maintain a stable symbiosis.

This research shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools. This is a major step forward in the effort to reduce the school-to-prison pipeline. It also shows that it is possible to change the mindsets of teachers, which can have a major impact on the quality of relationships between teachers and students.

This study provides a comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms of transcription stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The results from this study are expected to be useful for the development of novel therapeutic agents for cancer treatment.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions must be cleaved sequentially by endosomal proteases to enter cells, and the first cleavages are required for virus entry into human lung-derived cells. Here, we show that the first cleavages are important determinants of virus virulence, because they expand the cell tropism of MERS-CoV to cell types that are relevant to lung infection. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are important determinants of the pathogenicity of other viruses that require sequential proteolysis for entry.

This study provides robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available from 25 to 50% (e.g., from 1 in 4 to 2 in 4 options) increased vegetarian meal sales by 61.8% in the observational study and by 40.8% in the experimental study. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. The results also suggest that the impact of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available is likely to be larger in the early stages of a campaign than in the later stages. This is an important finding, as it suggests that the impact of a campaign to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available could be maximized by starting with a large increase in the proportion of vegetarian meals available and then gradually reducing the proportion of vegetarian meals available over time. This approach could be used to maximize the impact of a campaign to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we show that the surfaceome is dramatically remodeled in a panel of breast cancer cell lines expressing a variety of oncogenes, and that this remodeling is driven by the oncogenes themselves. We also show that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion, and that this is accompanied by changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on the 2020 election. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.
The structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein is presented.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the clinic, and it is also a natural condition in the human body. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema in hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapies for this potentially life-threatening condition. (Read more)

The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from data. However, the more data we have, the more difficult it becomes to find the “true” associations. This is the problem of “selective inference.” We describe some recent developments in selective inference and show how they can be used to make better inferences in a variety of settings.

This study provides a new method for the generation of endothelial cells, which are essential for the formation of blood vessels. This method can be used to generate endothelial cells for the treatment of vascular disorders and for the formation of vascular networks in the regeneration of organs.

This is a study of the function of a protein that is not part of the main signaling pathway in the cell. The study is important because it shows that a protein that is not part of the main signaling pathway in the cell can have a function of its own.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well-established, the underlying mechanisms of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction remain to be further elucidated. Herein, we provide evidence that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. More importantly, we establish the pathophysiological significance of STING in β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of T2D and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is a feature that provides evolutionary advantages but also complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of two viral RNA segments into each virion. This mechanism is sequence dependent and involves interactions between the viral RNA segments that are not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. This mechanism might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide a better understanding of the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. They also provide a possible explanation for the lack of reassortant viruses in the current pandemic. (Read more)

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The results suggest that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the subsequent development of atherosclerotic lesions. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for the prevention of atherosclerosis.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but their economic and ecological costs have risen dramatically in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a chemosensory receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has been linked to microcephaly and other neurological disorders. The current outbreak has led to a global concern for the safety of pregnant women. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model, which allows for the characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the time between infection and the onset of symptoms is short, and that the rate of viral production is rapid. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by ∼2 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results provide a better understanding of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection, and can be used to inform the development of effective antiviral therapies. (Less)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is caused by a loss of the symbiotic association with zooxanthellae. This process is often triggered by environmental stressors, such as ocean warming. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts play a crucial role in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn leads to the degradation of the coral–algal symbiosis. This process is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the host’s energy limitation. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn, trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and lead to a loss of barrier function. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond to it. In this study, we show that treatment with chemotherapy enhances the expression of ROR1 in breast cancer cells, and that ROR1 expression is associated with the development of breast cancer stemness. Furthermore, we show that targeting ROR1 with an anti-ROR1 antibody, which is a humanized antibody, can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize, and improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be an effective strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which is thought to have led to a reduction in precipitation and a change in the atmospheric circulation. However, the timing of this change is not well constrained. Here, we show that a series of volcanic eruptions, which occurred exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn may have caused changes in the atmospheric circulation. These changes may have led to the observed changes in climate and the start of deglaciation. This study provides a new perspective on the causes of the start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere. View Full-Text

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that the majority of catches come from regions with high levels of human population density and river discharge. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished, and that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the need to protect these ecosystems. Our data can be used to inform the design of effective conservation and management strategies for freshwater fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are revealed, which is expected to be a key factor for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a hallmark of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate are not well understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to be required for regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of novel genes that control the ability of neurons to regenerate. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate is not a fixed property of the nervous system, but rather is a dynamic property that can be modulated by a variety of factors.

The distribution of recombination across a genome is a key factor in determining the rate of evolution. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we show that the pattern is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in activity that are thought to reflect the organization of the brain into functional networks. Here, we show that the organization of the resting brain can be mapped in a noninvasive manner, using a technique that measures the metabolic activity of the brain. This approach provides a direct measure of the organization of the brain, which can be used to study the resting brain in health and disease.
This is a study of the structure and function of a molecule that is not yet well-characterized.

This study shows that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood is altered in people with diabetes, and that these alterations persist over time. These findings support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These results also suggest that epigenetic modifications may be a target for therapeutic interventions to improve metabolic memory.
This is a study on the role of a protein in cancer.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease, which is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, and that some of them develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the disease and in the maintenance of the behavioral and physiological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

This study provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of volatile nitrogen-containing compounds in plants. These compounds are of particular importance in the flavor of many fruits, and the identification of the pathway for their production will be of great value in the development of improved cultivars.

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be exacerbated by biodiversity loss. This is because the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and the temperature tolerance of species is a key determinant of the magnitude of this relationship. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of climate change on biodiversity in the context of ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode information about the location of objects, head direction, and the local environment. Here, we show that the neurons that encode information about the local environment are organized into distinct clusters, which are anatomically and functionally segregated. These data provide a framework for understanding the organization of the MEC and its role in navigation.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal in the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates the importance of flowering as a signal for flowering in plants, and it also shows that flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes.

This study provides a detailed description of the morphology of the dopamine system in the human brain. The striatonigral bouquet is a new type of structure that has not been described before. It is a highly specialized structure that is likely to be important for the function of the dopamine system.

We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected they feel. This finding has implications for our understanding of the nature of social connection, the evolution of human communication, and the design of social technologies.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cells that are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. This study reveals that the activity of these cells is regulated by a mechanism that links the content of calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum with the activity of the plasma membrane. This mechanism is mediated by a protein called STIM1.

Silicon (Si) is a ubiquitous element in the terrestrial environment, and its beneficial effects on plant growth and development have been well documented. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, and that this effect is dependent on the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may promote the accumulation of JA in rice, which in turn enhances resistance against insect herbivores. These findings provide insights into the potential of Si as a biocontrol agent for insect pests. (Less)

This study is a continuation of our previous work on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in the metabolism of ether lipids in macrophages. We found that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also found that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a sustained increase in neural activity. However, there is also evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation plays a role in memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is able to capture the essential features of memory, including the effects of interference and the binding of information over time. This work provides a computational framework for understanding the neurobiology of language. It also provides a new perspective on the nature of memory and its role in cognition.

This work is a step forward in the development of a new class of delivery systems for biomolecules to plants. The work is expected to be useful for the development of a new class of delivery systems for biomolecules to plants.

Eutrophication is one of the greatest threats to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes is from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies, and that their nutrient loads are often high for their size. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small subset of chemical concentrations. We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the available environmental work. This work is of interest in the context of the search for “robust” steady states, which are stable against perturbations in the chemical network and the environment. Our results suggest that the search for robust steady states should be extended to the study of the extremization of environmental work.

This study provides a detailed description of the mechanisms underlying the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain. The results are expected to be of interest to the neuroscience community, as they provide a detailed description of the mechanisms underlying the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain.

The history of Earth’s climate is a history of abrupt changes. These changes are often linked to changes in atmospheric CO2, which is a key driver of climate. Here, we present a study of one of the most extreme changes in atmospheric CO2, which occurred at the end of the Permian.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification has a positive impact on the rate of deforestation, but that this impact is largely due to the certification of plantations that are already small and contain little residual forest.

The exocytosis process is essential for the functioning of all organisms. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all organisms. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all organisms.

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a key component of the evolution of sexual dimorphism. In this study, we show that the genetic basis of sex determination in a cichlid fish can produce a modular system of sexual dimorphism, where the same genetic locus can produce different phenotypes in different individuals. This system of sexual dimorphism is not only modular, but also can be expanded by the acquisition of new alleles. This system of sexual dimorphism may be a model for the evolution of sexual polymorphism.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the presence of iron is known to promote oxidative damage. However, the role of iron in the retina is not well understood. Here, we show that the presence of iron in retinal pigment epithelial cells promotes the oxidation and degradation of a bisretinoid pigment, A2E, which is a key component of the retinal pigment epithelium. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of iron in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

Siphonophores are a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentilla (tentacle side branches armed with nematocysts) for prey capture. This is a highly specialized mode of feeding, and the only one in the animal kingdom. We show that siphonophores are a highly specialized group of predators, and that the evolution of their tentilla is linked to the prey type. Our results suggest that the evolution of predator specialization is linked to the evolution of the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of the organisms involved.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic features of human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus.
This is a study of the role of a metabolic enzyme in cancer.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is likely to be exacerbated by fragmentation of forests. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, and the need to consider the impact of land use change on people’s diets.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased food production by 170% over the last 60 y. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the paradox of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction, including the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, may be the result of the same phenomenon.
